revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2003 |Team=Iowa Hawkeyes |Image= |ImageSize= |Conference=Big Ten Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big Ten |CoachRank=8 |APRank=8 |Record=10-3 |ConfRecord=5-3 |HeadCoach=[[Kirk Ferentz]]{{cite web|title = Kirk Ferentz|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/ferentz_kirk00.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-18}} |OffCoach=[[Ken O'Keefe]] |DefCoach=Norm Parker |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Kinnick Stadium]]
Capacity: 70,585{{cite web|title = Kinnick Stadium|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/facilities/iowa-kinnick-stadium.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-18}} |Champion=Outback Bowl Champions |BowlTourney=[[2004 Outback Bowl|Outback Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult=W 37-17 vs. [[2003 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] }} {{2003 Big Ten football standings}} The '''2003 Iowa Hawkeyes football team''' represented the [[University of Iowa]] during the [[2003 NCAA Division I-A football season|2003 college football season]]. Following a [[2002 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|2002 season]] that saw the Hawkeyes finish 11-2 with a [[Big Ten Conference football champions|Big Ten championship]], expectations for a third straight [[bowl game|post-season game]] were well warranted.{{cite news|title = Iowa Hawkeyes 2003 Preview|url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/college/2003/preview/teams/iowa/|publisher = SI.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-18}} With four [[Offense (sports)|offensive]] starters and seven [[Defense (sport)|defensive]] starters returning from the 2002 season, the Hawkeyes looked to be a primarily defensive team going into the season. The Hawkeyes opened the season strong, winning games over [[2003 Miami RedHawks football team|Miami]], {{cfb link|year=2003|team=Buffalo Bulls|title=Buffalo}}, {{cfb link|year=2003|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} and {{cfb link|year=2003|team=Arizona State Sun Devils|title=Arizona State}} en route to a 4-0 record.{{cite web|title = Iowa 2003 Football Schedule/Results|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/teamsched?teamId=2294&year=2003|publisher = ESPN|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-18}} Undefeated and ranked ninth in the country, the Hawkeyes headed into [[East Lansing, Michigan|East Lansing]], [[Michigan]] for their [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] opener.{{cite news|title = Iowa vs. Michigan State|url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores103/103270/20030927NCAAFMICHIGANST0nr.htm|publisher = USA Today|date = 2003-09-27|accessdate = 2007-10-18}} Playing a [[2003 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State Spartans]] team that had just beaten [[2003 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]] a week earlier, the Hawkeyes turned the ball over four times and committed ten penalties in a 20â10 loss. However, with [[2003 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]] next up on the schedule, things would get no easier for the Hawkeyes. Before the game, Michigan held a 37-9-4 lead in the series between the two teams.{{cite web|title = Iowa Returns Home to Host Michigan on Homecoming|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/092903aab.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = 2003-09-29|accessdate = 2007-10-18}} Down by 14 in the first quarter for the second straight game,{{cite web|title = No. 19 Iowa 30, No. 9 Michigan 27|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/100403aab.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = 2003-10-04|accessdate = 2007-10-19}} the Hawkeyes came back to take a 30â20 lead midway through the fourth quarter. Michigan threatened the Iowa lead late, but the Hawkeyes held on for the 30â27 victory.{{cite news|title = Michigan vs. Iowa|url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores103/103277/20031004NCAAFIOWA------0nr.htm|publisher = USA Today|date = 2003-10-04|accessdate = 2007-10-19}} After the victory, Iowa lost on the road to [[2003 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]], but followed with home wins over {{cfb link|year=2003|team=Illinois Fighting Illini|title=Illinois}} and [[2003 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]]. With a loss to [[2003 Purdue Boilermakers football team|Purdue]], Iowa's record was 7-3 with two regular season games remaining. Playing against [[2003 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] and the [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]]'s top-ranked offense, the Hawkeyes scored 33 points before the Gophers scored a [[touchdown]].{{cite news|title = Minnesota vs. Iowa|url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores103/103319/20031115NCAAFIOWA------0nr.htm|publisher = USA Today|date = 2003-11-15|accessdate = 2007-10-19}} Following the 40â22 victory, the Hawkeyes fell behind unranked [[2003 Wisconsin Badgers football team|Wisconsin]] 21â7 during the second quarter. Needing a pass deflection in the [[end zone]] by [[Sean Considine]] with no time remaining, the Hawkeyes scored 20 straight points and escaped with a 27â21 win and a 9-3 regular season record.{{cite news|title = Iowa vs. Wisconsin|url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores103/103326/20031122NCAAFWISCONSIN-0nr.htm|publisher = USA Today|date = 2003-11-22|accessdate = 2003-10-19}} Playing in the [[2004 Outback Bowl]] on January 1, 2004, the Hawkeyes won their first game in the state of [[Florida]] with a 37â17 victory over the [[2003 Florida Gators football team|Florida Gators]]. The win was also Iowa's first in the month of January since [[1959]].{{cite news|title = Iowa vs. Florida|url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores104/104001/20040101NCAAFFLORIDA---0nr.htm|publisher = USA Today|date = 2004-01-01|accessdate = 2007-10-19}} == Previous season == {{main|2002 Iowa Hawkeyes football team}} Behind strong performances by [[quarterback]] [[Brad Banks]], who finished second in the [[Heisman Trophy|Heisman]] voting,{{cite web|title = Brad Banks|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/banks_brad00.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-19}} and the Hawkeye rushing defense, which finished fifth-best in the country, Iowa finished 11-2 and shared the Big Ten championship with undefeated [[2002 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]].{{cite web|title = Big Ten Conference Football Standings 2002|url = http://www.goldfan.com/bigten/a02big.shtml|publisher = GoldFan.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-19}} Despite losses to Iowa State and [[USC Trojans football|Southern California]], the Hawkeyes finished with an 8-0 conference record that included wins over Michigan and Penn State. Iowa's lopsided 34â9 victory over Michigan in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan|Ann Arbor]] was Michigan's worst home loss since [[1967]].{{cite news|title = Iowa shines in rare romp|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_20021027/ai_n12478725|publisher = Chicago Sun-Times|date = 2002-10-27|accessdate = 2007-10-19}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} The eleven wins are, to date, an Iowa record for wins in a single season.{{cite web|title = Iowa completes undefeated Big Ten season|url = http://www.centralohio.com/ohiostate/stories/20021117/football/390228.html|publisher = CentralOhio.com|date = 2002-11-17|accessdate = 2007-10-19 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071123144628/http://www.centralohio.com/ohiostate/stories/20021117/football/390228.html |archivedate = 2007-11-23}} == Before the season == === Recruiting class === On [[National Signing Day]], February 5, 2003, the Hawkeyes signed 22 players on [[Athletic scholarship|football scholarships]].{{cite web|title = Brock Ita|url = http://iowa.scout.com/a.z?s=8&p=8&c=1&nid=584409|publisher = Scout.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-20}} === Rankings === Entering the season, Iowa was unranked by both major polls.{{cite web|title = 2003 NCAA Football Rankings - Preseason (Aug. 17)|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/rankingsindex?seasonYear=2003&weekNumber=1&seasonType=2|publisher = ESPN|date = 2003-08-17|accessdate = 2007-10-26}}{{cite web|title = 2003 NCAA Football Rankings - Preseason (Aug. 17)|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/rankings?seasonYear=2003&weekNumber=1&seasonType=2&pollId=2|publisher = ESPN|date = 2003-08-17|accessdate = 2007-10-26}} However, the Hawkeyes would debut in the [[Coaches Poll]] as the 25th-ranked team before their first game against [[Miami University]].{{cite web|title = 2003 NCAA Football Rankings - Week 1 (Aug. 24)|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/rankings?seasonYear=2003&weekNumber=2&seasonType=2&pollId=2|publisher = ESPN|date = 2003-08-24|accessdate = 2007-10-26}} ==
